subNodes.conversationText:
"More or less, less or more.
There's the chair, and there's the door.
There's a house without a floor.
There's an apple, there's its core."
"You're almost ready. You're young for a witch, but so was our last third. And there's no shame in youth," said Eldest Lady, pinching <FirstName>'s cheek. It hurt.
"When I was young, I did lots of shameful things."
"You did them shamelessly. The old do shame with shame in their hearts."
"Then you're as good as young, sister. No shame, no heart."
"Did your vision show you what happened to Nnenne, the last witch we bound to us?"
"It showed me that she'd been killed, but not how."
"As I expected. The circumstances of her death are hidden from our sight, and they are hidden from yours as well."
"The signs were confusing. I don't remember seeing that."
"As I expected. The circumstances of her death are hidden from our sight, and they are hidden from yours as well."
"I knew only that I was wanted here."
"What a dull vision. You're here now and therefore no longer wanted."

Eldest Lady ignored Middle One.

"As I expected. The circumstances of her death are hidden from our sight, and they are hidden from yours as well."
"Gone for good -- and likely gone bad by now --"
"Was off picking juneberries to make us tarts."
"But we're tarts already, so she quit."
"No, Middle One. She quit because she was shot."
"When we found her, she was dead. She had tried to run back with an arrow in her side."
"An unkind fate. I hope it's not an omen."
"What kind of talk is that for a witch? Fate's not kind -- not unkind either. In any case, you're not here to hope, but to act."
"A hunter, we believe. Not a witch hunter, mind you. A hunter of game."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"We want you to find the killer."
"More importantly, we want you to bring us the killer's blood. We'll use it for the binding."

"Yes, bring it! Bring it! What does the hunter's blood taste like? Bring it to us."

Roused, Pharaoh stretched his wings and bobbed his head.
"No, Middle One. There will be no tasting."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
"She needs the blood to warm her own."
"We'll appease Nnenne with her killer's blood and anoint the one who follows her with the same. It's all very suitable."
"Whose blood would you use if there was no one to avenge?"
"So be it. I will hunt this hunter."
"Whose blood would you use if there was no one to avenge?"
"If we had no one to avenge," said Eldest Lady, "you wouldn't be here."
"So be it. I will hunt this hunter."
"So be it. I will hunt this hunter."

"Good. The arrow, Middle One."

Middle One held forth an arrow. It was long and straight, and it had goose fletching. Dried blood was on the point, shaft, and feathers.

Eldest Lady spoke again. "Three hunters live in these woods. My magic has told me that one of them is responsible, but it tells me no more than this. Take this arrow and find the one who shoots with arrows of the same make. Kill them and bring back a pint of their blood."

"Good. Just one more thing."

"Go into the backyard. There you'll find Nnenne's grave. Nearby is a little table with a seed, trowel, and some water."

"Dig a hole in the grave, plant the seed, and water it."

Tall grasses and wildflowers had overtaken the witches' backyard. Abandoned charms, half-empty jars, and rusty tools were strewn through the grass.

Near the border of the woods was a fresh grave, dug between two vegetable patches where tomato plants sprawled. A shaft of sunlight illuminated the plot and a name crudely carved on the stone marker. "NNENNE," it said.

heard someone lock the door behind . The witches would not let back in until 'd finished task.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY!
The Three Hunters: Planting the Seed

Eldest Lady and Middle One sent the young witch into their back yard. There rested the body of the witch who'd been shot. The young witch was told to plant a seed in the soil of her grave.

subNodes.conversationText: "This arrow can't conclusively prove who did this."
"Is it a witch, or is it a lawyer? Aroint thee, clerk."
"Magic can make blood talk. Get the blood and then we'll know for sure."
"Not a very efficient way of pursuing justice."
"Bah. Flesh is flesh. You're young, <FirstName>, but it's time to set aside these young ideas. The world is old and wicked."
"Then may I take the right blood."
"But the hunter was wrong to do what he did. Take, therefore, the wrong blood."
"Don't listen to Middle One's nonsense. You will choose rightly."
"A hunter, we believe. Not a witch hunter, mind you. A hunter of game."
"Very well. I hope fate is kinder to me."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"Who knows? She was a witch, and witches are not always loved. And she was beautiful, and destruction always prefers beauty."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"An unkind fate. I hope it's not an omen."
"We want you to find the killer."
"What does this have to do with me?"
"Very well. I hope fate is kinder to me."
"What kind of talk is that for a witch? Fate's not kind -- not unkind either. In any case, you're not here to hope, but to act."
"We want you to find the killer."

"Enough. Go curdle milk. Go kill swine."

But Middle One only hummed a little and made no sign of going anywhere.

Eldest Lady turned to the young witch. "We need to talk about some things. You know the Laws, yes?"
"The Three Laws of Covens? Of course."
"Do no harm to anyone in the coven --" <FirstName> began.
<He/She> continued: " -- No harm to anyone, including yourself. Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Finally, the witches' number must always be three."
"Every witch knows the Laws, but they're not just words. Without a third, Middle One and I do not make a coven. Our powers are weak, and we grow feeble."
"Did your vision show you what happened to Nnenne, the last witch we bound to us?"
"Rule number one: 'The youngest witch gets the biggest bed.'"
"The youngest witch gets the biggest bed," repeated Middle One. "The earth is the biggest bed."
"One: Do no harm to anyone in the coven -- including yourself. Two: Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Three: The witches' number must always be three."
But <FirstName> drew a blank. "I've forgotten. I must be too nervous."
"One: Do no harm to anyone in the coven -- including yourself. Two: Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Three: The witches' number must always be three."
The two witches had been waiting for <him/her>. Middle One and Eldest Lady were their names. They were quick to get to the point.
